top_comment.text:
I don't like the way Studio C has been going. I've been a fan for a long 
time, and their videos have gotten more and more inappropriate and 
disgusting. It makes me sad because I've enjoyed this show for a long time, 
and now I don't feel comfortable watching it with my family, or even myself 
at times.﻿
top_comment.author: Ultrachessmaster

comments.text:
+Ultrachessmaster I'm not sure I quite understand what you mean. I hope you 
know I do respect your opinion, and I find it admirable that you are doing 
your best to uphold your standards. If I may ask, could you please explain 
what you mean a bit more? Some specific examples of what you mean or what 
you find inappropriate or offensive so that I can get a better picture of 
your view? Thanks so much!
comments.author: Morgan Dennis

comments.text:
+TPGFan Yeah, I just hoped that I could feel a bit more comfortable 
watching Studio C, because I honestly love this show. Like you said, I'll 
have to find something else to watch.
comments.author: Ultrachessmaster

comments.text:
+Ultrachessmaster
Well, we've tried to share our opinions on this, and you've shared yours. 
Neither side is going to convince the other if the above posts are anything 
to go by.

I say we stop here and just enjoy whatever it is we like. Those of us who 
are not offended by these sketches can continue watching, and you can watch 
something else you enjoy.

I applaud you for being as resolute about your standards as you are.

I don't think further conversation will do much besides potentially 
offending somebody. Let's just end this here with only civil, reasoned 
words in the conversation.
comments.author: TPGFan

comments.text:
+Morgan Dennis I think that's too many little instances with a different 
excuse for each one. And I honestly find some of the things in the sketches 
you mentioned more offensive than you did.
comments.author: Ultrachessmaster

comments.text:
Personally, I think all you guys are reading way too much into things. I 
can understand that you might find things more offensive in these sketches 
than others might. But many of the specific examples you've given I found 
to lack substance. For example, the throwing down brides comment, and 
further comments that Studio C is showing its support of quote-on-quote 
"collecting woman" I believe is nor substantiated in these sketches. If 
anything at all, they're making fun of the fact that other people do use 
those things for entertainment (almost like they're taking a more satirical 
approach to their sketches). And, in the Taken 3 sketch where the bride was 
thrown down, she was one of many subjects that was stopped from "taking" 
anything--she was not at all singled out. Had the groom been thrown down, 
would the joke still be found offensive?

I do understand partially where you're coming from. In the taking bets 
sketch, I was a little wary, however they made the overall comment that in 
gambling no-one really wins, or it's highly unlikely you'd win and a 
wasteful use of time and energy. So, again, I saw more of a satirical 
sketch that effectively spoke against the action of taking bets and 
gambling. I can also see how someone might be offended by the Scott 
Sterling sketch because of the blood, but it wasn't intended to be 
inherently gruesome or overly violent, as are many forms of entertainment 
these days.

And as to the comments speaking against the inclusion of Spanish Matt 
Center, I must say I disagree entirely. Studio C was not including it to be 
offensive in any way, they included no stereotypes. All they did was have a 
guy speak in Spanish--saying essentially the same things that the English 
newscaster said.

I believe I understand at least somewhat of where you and others are coming 
from, and I respect your opinion and theirs, but I hope this may have 
helped you to see why many people who have high morals like unto yourself 
are not offended by the new and upcoming Studio C episodes. 

Thank You!
comments.author: Morgan Dennis

comments.text:
+Stuart Mayo
Have you ever been to utah? In the schools at least, it's a large 
percentage of "Non White" people. This is a comedy sketch. They aren't 
saying this is how spanish speakers speak or act. They are making fun of 
English-written Spanish television shows, and just newscasters in general.
comments.author: TPGFan

comments.text:
Man, it seems like everyones' comments are so insightful and pretty darn 
respectful for a youtube link. I wish you guys were in charge of news 
channels!
comments.author: Grace Algecera

comments.text:
+Ultrachessmaster
I don't know that they have been "Promoting" or "Encouraging" any of the 
things that Jason's character was doing. In fact, Matt is the only 
character in this sketch portrayed as being not insane. The hosts are 
shallow (Pretty normal, I guess) and the other characters are extreme 
stereotypes or so blatantly strange that it is that it is difficult to take 
them seriously, much less take them as a role model or anything. Sure, it 
might be offensive if you take it wrong. So could a lot of their sketches. 
Remember the poker sketch? They aren't promoting gambling, they are just 
using it as a setting where a lot of humor can be found. Just because 
something is in a sketch doesn't mean they are supporting or promoting it. 
Really though, it's good to know that there are still non-desensitized 
people in the world.
comments.author: TPGFan

comments.text:
+Jeffrey Chumley I agree with you there. +Stuart Mayo I agree with you 
about the Spanish channel thing. It was pretty funny in the first one, but 
it was a little much for this. It would have been much better if that was 
cut out.
comments.author: Chris Campbell

comments.text:
+Ultrachessmaster I think this sketch could be described as satire. It 
certainly wasn't an endorsement of Jason's character's approach. If you 
really want to probe for deep meaning (that may not be intended since this 
is a lighthearted show), the sketch suggests that "good guys" (Matt) with 
the right intentions often fail in receiving affection while womanizers 
(Jason) get the attention and affection. Subtle social commentary perhaps?
comments.author: Jeffrey Chumley

comments.text:
It's not so much disgusting as it is offensive. The Mexican channel needed 
to not be a thing in this video. That was so obviously for the people in 
Utah who have never seen anyone who isn't white.
comments.author: Stuart Mayo

comments.text:
No, it's probably about PG. Trust me, I see most films that come out, and I 
have a pretty good grasp on what makes a movie PG, PG-13 and R. G is almost 
a non-existent rating these days. It's still there, but it barely exists 
outside of the realm of crappy kids movies. 

And yeah, I think the fact that Studio C is doing stuff that's actually 
funny is only good PR for the Church. There is a misconception that we are 
these weirdos who are always perfect, and I think that just drives people 
away.
comments.author: Chris Campbell

comments.text:

learn to make light of minor character flaws taking the play out of work 
rest and play and have fun.  from ensign it says showing a bit of insanity 
shows true sanity through the principle of play and fun and comedy.  i hope 
it makes sense.  it does to me.  best to you all cya
